items.description: West Bay Harbour and Esplanade
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been issued due to the high spring tides and strong winds.
The forecast high water is between 05:00 AM and 08:00 AM on the 7th April 2024, with a total water level of 5.58 mAOD for West Bay and a Force 7 south-westerly wind.  All times are local and for more detail please refer to your local tide tables.  
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at properties along and behind the Esplanade, Quayside, Heron Court, Forty Foot Way, Driftwood, Fourviews, Britbank, Barwick, Sunset, Riverside, George Hotel, Colmer Lodge and the Parkdean Holiday Park. Localised standing water may affect the roads between the Parkdean Holiday Park and West Bay Road.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected but the main concern is around large waves and debris and stones causing damage.
Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. 
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 07/04/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high but steady on the River Loddon following a period of sustained rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 07/04/24 in the Twyford area​​.

The weather forecast for today 07/04/24 and tonight is mainly dry with the possibility of some blustery showers. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the next few days, but remain susceptible to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation.  Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid contact with flood water. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/04/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Chitterne Valley
items.message:
The groundwater level at the Chitterne Down borehole has risen to 100.12m above sea level and is forecast to reach 102.5m by Monday the 8th. For reference the peak level in January was 105.47m

The weather over the next two weeks will continue unsettled with a heavier band of rain expected on Friday. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising steadily overv the next week. 

Property flooding is expected and sewage systems may become inundated.

Residents should deploy any property flood resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers.
Avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave from vehicles can flood adjacent properties.

Do not lift manhole covers to alleviate local surface water flooding as this may cause toilets further downhill to surcharge.
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: Beaulieu estuary
items.message: Monday's early morning tide at 00:00 on 08/04/2024 and 01:03 on 08/04/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light South Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.43 m. The total forecast tide is 4.23 metres Chart Datum (2.23 mAOD) at Beaulieu. We will issue further advice tomorrow. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking or driving through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood the main road quickly. items.description: Christchurch Harbour Side
items.message:
Strong winds and spring tides are causing large waves and spray overtopping on the coast this evening, and flooding is predicted from now until the turn of the tide in the next 2 hours (00:00).  We expect flooding to affect areas in close proximity to Christchurch Harbour including Mudeford, Stanpit, the Quomps and Wick areas Willow Way (Quomps), including Watermead and Kingfishers developments. 
Weather conditions are expected to produce large offshore waves.
High tide levels may prevent rivers from flowing to the sea and cause rivers to rise.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
If you have not already done so, please consider installing property flood resilience equipment. Please stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as the expected large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings. 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 07/04/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Haverigg
items.message:
Sunday morning's tide at 11:15 AM is higher than normal due to Storm Kathleen which is bringing strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
Flooding is possible at low lying areas along the coast from St Bees Head to Haverigg including Ravenglass and Annaside between 9:15 AM and 1:15 PM on 07/04/2024.
Sunday evening's high tide is not expected to reach the flood alert level but we are expecting higher than normal tides over at least the next 5 days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 6:00 PM on 07/04/2024, or as the situation changes.
